clinical_study.brief_title: Thoracodorsal Artery Perforator Flap Versus Conventional Free Flaps
clinical_study.official_title: Thoracodorsal Artery Perforator Flap Versus Other Conventional Free Flaps in Soft Tissue Reconstruction

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy of the thoracodorsal artery perforator flap versus other conventional free flaps for reconstruction of soft tissue defects.

detailed_description.textblock:
The field of plastic surgery, unlike most other surgical specialties, has no anatomic or functional area to which it can lay claim; the plastic surgeon practices methods and techniques applicable to all specialties and anatomic areas.
Reconstructive surgery is the process of restoring the human body to "whole" following tumor extirpation, infection, trauma or congenital or acquired deformity - restoring both form and function.
The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy of the thoracodorsal artery perforator flap versus other conventional free flaps for reconstruction of soft tissue defects.

primary_outcome.description: the time from the start to the end of operation

secondary_outcome.measure: The percentage of patients with Flap viability
secondary_outcome.description: The perforator flap will be assessed regarding (color, temperature, capillary refilling, congestion, blistering)

intervention.description: fascio-cutaneous flap used in cases of trauma or burns
musculo-cutaneous flap used in cases of trauma or burns

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
• Soft tissue loss anywhere in the body.
Exclusion Criteria:
• Patients with chronic debilitating diseases e.g. chronic renal failure, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
